FOREWORD
The following is a transcript of an oral interview conducted by the authors of the World Bank' s fiftieth anniversary history: John P. Lewis, Richard Webb and Devesh Kapur, The World Bank: Its First Half Century, Washington, DC: Brookings Institution Press, 1997. It is not a formal oral history, and it is not a systematic overview of the work of the person interviewed. At times the authors discussed the planned publication itself and the sources that should be consulted; at other times they talked about persons and publications extraneous to the Banlc Some interview tapes and transcripts begin and end abruptly. Nevertheless, the World Bank Group Archives believes that this transcript may be of interest to researchers and makes it available for public use.

SIREGAR: They were so much impressed by the government transmigration program in {inaudible] with the belief that we followed where others have . . .
But in reality ..
LEWIS: About when did that happen?
SIREGAR: I believe that was in some-when we started with transmigration projects in West Sumatra-'79, I think. Around that time.
L EWIS: Around there?
SIREGAR: But at that time, the oil boom and the government has a lot of money, and they spent billions of rupiah, buy- what do you call it- buy the bulldozer and those things. We had a lot of money from the oil.
And then the World Bank--! don't know; this is my personal opinion--maybe World Bank watch it and say, "Why am I not involved?" Maybe, I don't know. Maybe! Please don't quote me on that! Maybe. This project done by the government, World Bank was not involved. So, you know if you are in the World Bank, you ask the question, maybe. Yeah! Yeah! Yeah!
WEBB: A piece of the action.
SIREGAR: But why government could do that? Because they want to? They have a lot of money, so transmigration program was one of the programs is very much far behind other sectors in the Bank. Government people saw it first. And at the same time the minister of transmigration was appointed just to show how serious government has thought that this issue was.
LEWIS: And now is the perception that it's not very successful--I mean within the government generally?
SIREGAR: [inaudible]
Muchtarudin Siregar November 26, 1991 - Verbatim  18
LEWIS: It's subsided? It's not going on at the same rate?
SIREGAR: Ah, because there are, you know, speaking about [inaudible] activities, you know, but still one of the big projects.
LEWIS: l see.
WEBB: We've seen often in many countries that the Bank follows a cycle like that. They get very enthusiastic about something, then five, ten years later they are criticizing about all of it: "That was a big mistake." Do you see many cases of that here?
SIREGAR: Uh ... not so many. Maybe the good example would be transmigration.
W EBB: That's the one example. Other ..
SIREGAR: Maybe you can find, maybe plantation [inaudible] but I don't know the examples.
WEBB: They've been more consistent here?
SIREGAR: Not much. I can see only transmigration. I can see clearly, but others {inaudible}
LEWIS: Has there been discussion here about the Bank getting into employment programs?
SIREGAR: No.
LEWIS: Have they done much?
SIREGAR: Yeah, they are helping the Department of Manpower.
LEWIS: Manpower?
SIREGAR: Yeah.
LEWIS: This is urban or rural employment?
SIREGAR: Both.
LEWIS: Both. They help by what, by technical assistance?
SIREGAR: Yeah, I think. I don't remember [inaudible} It's already discussed every time in the economic report. We have a--what do you call it--economic report that's presented in the IGGI. It's an evaluation by the World Bank presented to the IGGI, employment and everything like that always is covered in the topics discussed. They are

very much concerned about it. Even maybe there are not so many loans, sectors, but ...
LEWIS: Well, that would certainly be local cost financing, if they were to add to it.
SIREGAR: Yeah, a local cost financing example is the labor-intensive projects by the government of Indonesia.
WEBB: Which ones?
SIREGAR: The labor-intensive.
WEBB: What would they ..
SIREGAR: Yeah, we call it, Instruksi Presiden [Presidential Instruction} projects for the urban and the rural areas.
KAPUR: In the 20-odd years, 24 years, since ' 68 when the Bank has been here, there has been a lot of changes within Indonesia. Have you had a sense of any changes in the World Bank's approach to development?
SIREGAR: I did not follow. What was your ...
KAPUR: Well, like within Indonesia itself the economy has changed and developed, in terms of their development philosophy.
SIREGAR: Oh, they follow Indonesia. They are [inaudible} change since then.
LEWIS: The Bank follows you, then?
SIREGAR: Yeah. They try--they have their own, but so far we don't see any {inaudible} concerning this idea. For instance, when we prepare our Repelita, they have also their own assessment, but in the formal rule is very much developed. For instance, when we start our first Repelita, they only come to us: " Stick to what we call a project loan." Project loan means they follow everything with regard to the project which is limited to that. "Then after 15 years, go more and more to what we call the sectoral loan." It is just [inaudible} They see our capital is already much improved, and then--I don't know; when was it? ' 81, ' 82? We start with a sectoral loan. I mean-yeah, it is not only when the World Bank teach us to do [inaudible] but they always accept us to do {inaudible} Indonesia.
{End Tape 1} {Begin Tape 2]
LEWIS: Usually in the Bank when somebody is like that, they get accused of being more Indonesian than the Indonesians. But that didn't apply to Bernie for some reason. The Bank doesn't criticize him in that regard. It's a very common complaint about people,

after all, that they go native, you know. [Laughte1]
SIREGAR: He has helped us a lot because he sometimes could go straight to the top.
LEWIS: Yeah, he could do that.
SIREGAR: Not by-passing but, you know, to make us more. He has also been near the negotiations in Washington. If a program is, you know, [inaudible}
LEWIS: Which negotiations?
SIREGAR: Negotiations in Washington. For instance, if a program is ..
LEWIS: Oh.
SIREGAR: .. is going to pot, the Indonesian delegation will always consult with Bernie and then [inaudible} Colleagues in our negotiations have told me we always say there is an Indonesian Mafia, Colin O' Farrell {phonetic) told me. Maybe Bernie is the Indonesian Mafia in the World Bank. I don't know!
LEWIS: Right.
WEBB: In most countries that I know of you find people who admire the World Bank, but also there' s a lot of feeling of kind of some irritation and sometimes stronger, but you don't find much of that here.
SIREGAR: Well, you may. Sometimes, yes. Take, for instance, right here in this office, director general of sea transportation. So many issues, sometimes several issues very touchy politically and also administratively and of course maritime also. And when we had an admiral as the director general, he's already {inaudible} not the economic, more for- I don' t know. And we had the people in, the World Bank people, because the World Bank team came to me and said at this time, "This is what we should do in order to improve the shipping in Indonesia." So, so many requirements, covenants.
WEBB: I can imagine.
SIREGAR: Then you know what the director general said? "You and the World Bank are going to run this country, or what?" Then no more road map after that. Only one road in maritime. [Laughter} It happens sometimes.

SIREGAR: Not now, but in the past, yes, a lot.

doc.abstracts: In November 1991, Muchtarudin Siregar interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by John Lewis, Richard Webb, Devesh Kapur. This transcript concerns serious negotiations between Indonesia with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in 1968; and the World Bank’s concentration on infrastructure in early ‘70s.
